messages: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:04): It looks like http://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/htmlbg/results only includes W3C IEs and Members in the Non-responders section
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:04): On the other hand, it seems like everyone can vote...
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:05): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: indeed - DanC said that was a bug
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:05): in the survey tool
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:05): I'm surprised that there is nog a single no vote
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (11:08): Formal Objections must be justified. The "No"s will spend more time considering than the "yes"es.
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:09): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884, could you run "javascript:alert(document.getElementsByTagName('a')[0].pathname)" on something like google.com/search ?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:09): in Safari
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:09): It seems that pathname differs for window.location and <a>
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:10): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: just a sec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:10): the list of people who haven't voted is more telling than the list of people who voted yes
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:11): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: "/url"
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:11): MSIE has "url"
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:11): Opera has "url?..." which is buggy and we fixed it to "url" now for MSIE compat
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:11): what about other browsers?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:12): but it's inconsistent with location.pathname which is not nice
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:12): huh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:12): interesting
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:12): what would Firefox do?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:12): never heard of any compat issues with the leading / problem
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:12): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884, Firefox does "/url", sorry
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:12): spec says /url
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:13): I haven't either, mainly cause I don't think sites use the broken out components on <a> much
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:13): the spec only defines it for location right?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:13): no
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:13): defines one algorithm, which will apply to both
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:13): might not be explicitly linked to both yet though
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:13): i meant the latter, but yeah, i expected as much
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:13): I wouldn't read too much into who hasn't voted yet
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:14): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 hasn't, for instance, and I doubt that is out of apathy
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:14): likewise no one from Opera has voted
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:14): opera did vote
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:14): i assume wilhelm removed his vote
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:14): since he's not the official rep :-)
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:14): he told me yesterday he was completely done with HTML5 and that he applied for XHTML2 IE status
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:14): lachy that is
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:14): will vote now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:14): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: uh huh
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:15): oh he's awake
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:15): runs
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:15): adele overwrote my vote, but she voted the same so I don't care
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:15): we never decided who was the official rep from apple
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:15): lbolstad will vote for Opera I think
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:16): he's been stated to be the official rep by others from Opera before
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:16): voted without talking to his other reps but figured his vote was a fair compromise anyway
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:16): it doesn't seem like a big deal for this group who is "official"
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:17): so how long ago did the group start, a little over a month?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:18): so 1 month and 3 weeks to starting to make our first decision of any substance
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:18): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I'm not sure about compat issues either with the /. I think we just want to be on the safe side
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:19): isn't sure there's much point in differing from IE here
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:23): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I'll ask about Window.postMessage()
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:24): Masatak Yakura commented "Wonders who'll be the authors." - I wonder why (s)he thinks authors and editors of specs are different people?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:25): Authors are also all the people who contribute
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:29): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: cool thanks
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:48): whoa, dsr is rude
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:48): just replied to him
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:49): "I think you owe it to the Web" ...
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:49): if anything, dsr owes us a better version of HTML4
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:59): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884, I think tag soup refers to HTML parsing in general
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:59): why don't people say "HTML" instead of "tag soup" then?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:59): since it sounds kind of perjorative, I always assumed it meant non-conforming content
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:59): as in "no more tag soup, use valid semantic markup"
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:00): not sure
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:00): or contrasting "tag soup" to "well-formed XML", as if HTML content is inherently nonconformant
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:01): at least they're not calling it "street HTML" which is what opera people call it :-)
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:03): actually I like that better
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:03): it sounds kind of badass
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:03): like "street fighting"
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:03): hehe
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:03): or "street knowledge"
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:03): or "street smarts"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:05): mmmhm
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:06): wonders what DanC's original meaning of tag soup was (since he apparently coined the term)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:06): it's usually said like "gutter HTML"
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:09): wonders what Itunes' rumored deal with Gracenote for online song lyrics will do to the whole "How to mark up song lyrics" discussion...
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:09): I guess I'm not a fan of casually using perjoratives to refer to content formats
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:09): but maybe we should start calling XML "tag bondage" or something
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:10): can't comment on Apple rumors
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:11): 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4, where is the "how to mark up song lyrics" discussion?
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:12): It seems like every talk about markup inevitably uses song lyrics or poems as an example.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:13): HTML5 already solves that debate (though tantek would disagree :-))
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:13): Probably because those two cases have seemingly presentational needs that are arguably semantic.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:14): what presentational needs?  Just use <p> for each verse/chorus/etc. and <br> for line breaks within those.
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:15): refuses to get sucked into that discussion... :-)
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:18): you could have a <stanza> element instead, but that really doesn't seem better than reusing <p>
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:18): and it's not really clear if a verse or chorus is a stanza
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:18): <p class="stanza"> would be more appropriate
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:19): too hard
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:19): just use <p>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:19): <stanza> .. </stanza> <stanza> .. </stanza> wouldn't have good graceful fallback
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:20): well, <p> and <br> or <pre>
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:21): you'd want <pre> for an e.e. cummings poem

932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:21): In context of the rumor cited, I expect Gracenote will feed the data as a specialized XML format for the purpose (where e.g. a <stanza> element would make sense).
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:22): But sooner or later the consumer of that data will want to present it to a user, probably using an embedded web browser-ish view.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:22): as a courtesy I ask you not to talk about Apple rumors here
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:22): since that just makes the conversation more awkward for me
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:22): was trying to generalize himself away from the rumor...
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:23): askes 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 to leave so we can hear more rumors about Apple ;-)
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:23): I'm sure there's many places on IRC you can hear about hot apple rumors
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:24): Hey, there should be special markup for Apple rumors!
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:25): I once took some script code I had and marked it up in my own little XML-based bracket soup.
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:26): And then started looking at converting that to something a general web browser would display in a meaningfull way.
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:28): After many iterations it essentially ended up being a collection of deeply nested <div>s and <span>s.
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:28): All semantic meaning was hidden away in 'class' attributes.
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:29): And the markup weight was significantly larger then then actual content.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:31): quick survey results; 9/10 sites used <div> ... <br><br> ...</div> (or tables instead of div), 1/10 used <pre> for song lyrics

932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:31): It would be interesting to see what others would come up with in a similar situation, if their motivation was, say, shipping an actual product, rather then indulging a personal whim.
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:33): idly wonders what the syntax-coloring "View Source" functions in general browsers do here...
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (12:34): http://benjamin.smedbergs.us/blog/2006-07-18/marking-up-hymns/
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (12:54): the only tag that currently works easily for a poem is <pre>
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (12:55): poems have complex indentation, the best way to represent that I've found is let the user add the poem indented as they wish and capture that in a <pre> tag
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:00): not all poems have complex indentation
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:01): it varies per poem
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:02): which makes it even harder
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:02): feels like slapping everyone sending "+1"
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:03): "letter to andre billy" has stanzas that shape bottles, an eye and a cathedral
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:03): try that in html :)
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:07): that's clearly a use case for <pre>
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:07): oh wait, it's not just straight lines?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:08): if it's not, SVG or something might do it I suppose
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:08): I couldn't find letter to andre billy, do you have a pointer?
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:09): I've just looked and it's not on the interweb, I'll scan my copy and put it up
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:09): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guillaume_Apollinaire # the poet in question
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:09): http://www.netkonect.co.uk/~kram/apollin.htm
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:10): between the bottle and the cathedral should be an eye
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:10): "I see far away \ the cathedral"
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:11): XML is complex
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:12): HTLM tree construction is too, but at least HTML tokenization doesn't have weird stuff like the internal subset and all that
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:12): s/HTLM/HTML/
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:14): I think <pre> is fine for oddly formatted poetry
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:15): I don't get how the shape of the text is at all relevant to the poem, but then I always hated poetry and never understood it anyway
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:17): it's an extra layer of meaning
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:18): I still don't get what meaning it has
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:20): http://blue.carisenda.com/letter_to_andre_billy.jpg
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:21): i said bottle, the first shape is more likely a whistle :)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:23): ah, it makes a little more sense with the eye in it
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:24): is the cathedral supposed to be read as "OH MY DEAR ANDRE BILLY"?
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:24): i'm not an expert at explaining poetry, i'm just a consumer
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:25): i take it to mean that these things takes shape in his mind as he sits on the front line, there's not really there
